author: Dominic

text: After all these years, all the remakes of this track, this is still the best one. The more complicated and orchestral this track becomes, the more I feel it gets taken away from what it is supposed to represent. Humanity's final, desperate hope. A battle to decide the fate of their world, resting on the shoulders of these four hardened warriors. It's a track that tells a complete story. It cannot be improved upon. It was perfect in 1993, it is perfect now.

author: gurvmlk

text: @gurvmlk Technically, Lufia 2 is the first game of the series.
author: Anthony Murano

text:
@Anthony Murano All the more reason why I'm happy that I played the second game first. The Fortress of Doom totally spoils the ending of Rise of the Sinistrals in the first five minutes.

The trade-off being that it left me very disappointed when I finally did play Lufia 1, to the point where I initially hated the game, although I've since grown to like it. Not because I had unreasonably high expectations (it was made earlier, so naturally I expected it to not be as good), but because it didn't deliver in the ways I expected. Most notably, the puzzles. I went into Lufia 1 assuming those were a staple of the series, only to find the first game's dungeons to be generically dull and empty; the most bare-bones dungeons can be. Nor did it have things like capsule monsters, weapon/armor skills, or anything from Lufia 2 that's roots I expected to see in the first game.

author: Anthony Murano

text: @Anthony Murano: It was a terrible remake for many Lufia fans. Natsume dropped the ball on it majorly with all the changes made, and it bombed badly. It's fine if you like it, but the collective longtime fans have voiced their disappointment with it. It was a poor remake for many reasons and watered down too much of the original story while also rewriting quite a few of the characters' personalities (and not necessarily for the better).

author: JohnnyStyle300

text: A "Battery Back-up System" is the internal battery that allows you to save games on an SNES, GB, GBC, GBA, GameGear, SEGA, etc Cartridge. It keeps and maintains all the save files, highscores etc. if it dies however, you will lose all your save files and high scores, and will be unable to save until you replace the battery.

Erim doesn't become predictable till the 3rd one so either way there are surprises..I see your point about the prologue too but when you play II THEN I it's like your continuing your adventure..very badass.
author: operations1000

text: I disagree. I think it's cooler to play Lufia 1 first just so you know how amazingly powerful Maxim was at the end of Lufia 2. I like how Maxim fought all these really tough ass enemies at the beggining and then you fight even harder ones when you get to where he is. SO COOL
author: mopbrothers

text: It also kinda makes an odd conflict that Guy is still alive fuckin 99 years later yet you meet him as Jeros's son likely which would be Maxim's grandson. That part makes no sense lol unless if Maxim and Selan didn't die they woulda been alive just as long too cuz of their energy...still kinda weird. Artea makes sense, but not Guy.
author: operations1000

text: And that is because Lufia II was such a better game than Lufia...if it wasn't than I wouldn't have had such a great time playing Lufia II first then Lufia I. But playing II first makes you appreciate I AND II all the better...call me lucky I guess then :P
author: operations1000

text: Actually I played Lufia II first then Lufia and sure glad I did, it made the experience 100x better IMO. That's what a good prequel does.
author: operations1000

text:
The developers made Lufia 2 after everyone played the first one. They did a great job with it as far as making it seem like you're experiencing it for the first time as you play. Knowing what's going to happen (or at least part of what's going to happen, as the game continues after the part shown in Lufia 1 ends) does not ruin the experience at all. 

The added blast of nostalgia starting when the party enters Doom Island really helps.
author: zughiaq

text: They really should remake this game! I love how Maxim is really strong in the beggining fighting these tough enemies who he wastes and then it takes the whole game for you to get that strong too. What an EPIC game with EPIC music!

text: Yah me too, in Lufia II it sounds too watered down with too many beats added in but everything else music wise in Lufia II was brilliant compared to Lufia, especially the Sinistral Battle Music.
